captions.text:
I can&#39;t have been the only one who saw 
this coming up and thought, &quot;Hang on,

didn&#39;t this game come out in 2018?&quot; &quot;No, Yahtz, 
that was Monster Hunter World. Same title,

one different vowel.&quot; &quot;Oh, right. No, hang on, 
isn&#39;t this the one that came out in 2021?&quot; &quot;No,

Yahtz, that was Monster Hunter Rise. Same vowel, 
completely different consonants. This is Monster

Hunter Wilds.&quot; &quot;Oh, right. I&#39;m with you now. This 
is the game where you hunt giant monsters in a

pub in North Yorkshire while drinking pints 
of Moorhouse and Theakston Traditional. &quot;No,

Yahtz, that&#39;s Monster Hunter Milds. This 
is Monster Hunter Wilds.&quot; &quot;Oh, right,

this is the game where a giant monster jumps you 
in a dark alley and you wake up in a studio being

photographed in women&#39;s underwear in front 
of various pieces of antique furniture.&quot; &quot;No,

Yahtz, that&#39;s... I don&#39;t even know what 
the fuck that is.&quot; Seriously now, though,

Monster Hunter Wilds is a new instalment in the 
long-running Monster Hunter franchise, and it&#39;s

called that because it&#39;s set in the wilds, in 
contrast to every previous Monster Hunter game,

which were set in pedestrian precincts 
and multi-story car parks, sarcasm quotes.

Monster Hunter Wilds is set in the Forbidden 
Lands, a faraway realm of various inhospitable

terrains generally thought to be uninhabited, 
although I don&#39;t know how we got that impression,

&#39;cause once we get there, the place is fucking 
packed; maybe someone drew up a map and wrote

&quot;Here be dragons&quot; across it, and we didn&#39;t 
realize they meant that literally. The Hunter&#39;s

Guild discover it&#39;s inhabited when they&#39;re 
flying over it one day, getting some drone

shots for an upcoming YouTube documentary, and 
notice a lone child unconscious in the desert,

a member of a mysterious ancient tribe, and 
who is raised by the Hunter&#39;s Guild for a few

years before returning to the Forbidden Lands 
to track down what remains of their people and

realize their destiny. &quot;Boy, that sounds like 
a character who&#39;d make for a jolly interesting

protagonist,&quot; you might say. &quot;Yes, I suppose they 
would,&quot; replies the game. &quot;Anyway, here&#39;s you,

a completely different person. Some twat who 
hangs around the aforementioned destined child,

killing the giant monsters that keep getting 
in his way with slightly anomalous frequency

like he forgot to mention he&#39;s got a sausage in 
his back pocket. Please choose your appearance,

your cat&#39;s appearance, and your 
starting ridiculous outfit.&quot;

So, in short, Wilds has much of what you should 
expect if you&#39;re familiar with the Monster Hunter

experience—you explore a wilderness, collecting 
random shit; you fight the same giant monster over

and over again and use their bones, tendons, and 
nostril hairs to craft a better weapon that means

you can now kill the giant monster by hitting it 
9,000 times instead of 10. And also craft a new

outfit somehow even more ridiculous than your 
previous one. I had to laugh every time there

was a cutscene with your assistant who wears, 
like, a hoodie, and the blacksmith who wears,

like, a button-down shirt, presumably the one 
she&#39;s had since elementary school going by how

much skin it covers, and they&#39;ll turn to you 
and have no visible reaction to the fact we&#39;re

wearing a fucking six-eyed octopus head mask and 
a rippling muscle suit apparently carved out of

wood with a bunch of glowing antlers coming 
out of the shoulders that, in any sane world,

would&#39;ve all snapped off the first time we tried 
to dodge roll in it. I suppose it&#39;s only coming

across as silly now because Wilds actually has a 
surprising emphasis on telling a character-based

narrative, which moves along at a fair old clip, 
actually. You&#39;ve barely killed the monsters in the

starting wilderness map three times over before 
the game hurries you along to the next biome.

Each one featuring a new lost tribe of 
well-scrubbed people with inexplicably

strong command of English upon whom we get to 
go all colonial savior as we murder whatever

giant monsters are causing problems. &quot;Hunt the 
giant monsters?&quot; the natives then say. &quot;Gosh,

what a brilliant idea. We&#39;d never have thought 
of that. We were trying to live in harmony with

nature like a bunch of chumps. Thank goodness you 
white people showed up to set us right. Please,

enjoy this celebratory feast full of exotic 
foods being weirdly lovingly shot.&quot; So,

for the first 10 hours or so, the game basically 
speedruns a fairly standard RPG plot that ends

with us tracking down the giant monster that&#39;s the 
source of everyone&#39;s problems and killing it while

fake protagonist kid has some kind of epiphany 
while boggling at us from the little enclosure

marked &quot;place for characters with zero fucking 
agency.&quot; Roll credits. But after the credits,

the game basically goes, &quot;Right, now we&#39;ve got 
that out of the way, here&#39;s the actual Monster

Hunter game, open fucking wide.&quot; And wham, bunch 
o&#39; new monsters, side quests, special hunts,

the REAL weapons and weapon modifiers 
and shit all get added to the trough.

Rather interesting approach, actually, to have 
the campaign and the optional faffabout shit one

after the other rather than alongside each other 
as is usual; it&#39;s like having a lovely ice lolly

and then having a lovely stick to chew on. If 
the idea was to settle us in gently before the

real grind begins, then it kinda worked; I did 
get pretty into it, but I think it shows its

hand a bit too abruptly. See, throughout 
the initial handholdy, plot-driven part,

I never needed to kill a particular monster 
more than a couple of times to craft a new

weapon or armor from it; I actually began to 
labor under the delusion that I was good at

the game. But then post-credits, suddenly, 
it&#39;s all like, &quot;Now, for the next upgrade,

we need five of the thing this one monster only 
has a chance of randomly dropping if you kill it

by plugging its nostrils with your bollocks.&quot; No, 
bad game. Ramped up the grind too quick. Suddenly,

the first part feels less like an easing in 
and more the free first taste of heroin. Still,

there are things to be said for Monster Hunter 
Wilds even if the Stockholm syndrome fails to

kick in. I like how the wound system adds some 
much-needed texture to the process of smacking a

dude in the bum 9,000 times. There&#39;s an emphasis 
on getting around by riding mounted bird horse

things that aren&#39;t Chocobos—stop calling them 
that—from which you can use your grappling

hook to pick up resources without needing 
to stop, so traversal&#39;s pretty damn good.

Bit weird we can&#39;t use the grappling 
hook to grapple onto monsters, actually,

but maybe they don&#39;t want to spoil us in case 
we start expecting fulfilment and happiness

in everyday life. Jumping on the Chocothing and 
riding away for a bit is also a good way to get

out of the fight for a quick break since you can&#39;t 
pause with the online multiplayer focus. Well,

you can if you use single-player mode, but I 
couldn&#39;t because I was playing offline. I&#39;ll

pause for a moment while you figure out how 
that makes any fucking sense. Yes, that&#39;s the

other thing you should be expecting from Monster 
Hunter at this point: a really dogshit interface.

Getting my business done at camp was like wading 
through a mangrove swamp made of GUI menus. And

equipping and using items in the field is like 
ordering them over the phone without your credit

card close to hand. Still, that&#39;s another place 
the not-Chocobo comes in handy; I can just run

around the arena for a while, figuring out how 
to extract my whetstone from my dung pods. So,

y&#39;know. In the end, I had fun with Monster 
Hunter Wilds, so here&#39;s the final summary:

Not bad at all as Monster Hunters go, just 
bear in mind that where Monster Hunters go

is the place where the interfaces suck 
ass and you regularly have to whale on

leathery flesh for half an hour like a serial 
masturbator who just got his casts taken off.
